PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A general questionnaire

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1945, and may be interested in preserving experiences of the pioneer years whether or not they are still living.

Traces of the experiences of the family members covered by the questionnaire should be included here in response to each question.

The Questionnaire

Saskatchewan Archives Board has prepared a questionnaire to assist you in gathering information about your pioneer experiences. Please answer all questions to the best of your ability.

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives of the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of the province. Please return completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
SASKATOON, Saskatchewan.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES
No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name ____________________________
   Margaret Jeannette Stewart (Canadian name) Stewart

2. Your address ____________________________
   Mount St Mary's Home, Weyburn, Saskatchewan

3. Date ____________________________
   April 15, 1962

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country).
   Buckwill, Lanark County, Ontario 1881

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   Daniel Stewart, occupation farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year).
   May 1904

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   Came with parents to Manitoba 1885. Jan 1889 moved again with parents to North Dakota.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.)
   I was a small child

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   Moving west to homestead

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)
    Through other people. Everyone was moving west to homestead.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   All our friends and relatives believed that it would be a great future in the west.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   Traveled with parents and relatives on my father's side.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Traveled via CPR railroad.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   Crossing river was.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   When first stopping in Saskatchewan we stayed at Halbert with friends.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   Lomond municipality section 6, 4, 15 (south west of settlement near Mason)

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   Sold farm, then moved to Maxon. Leaving Maxon came to Weyburn.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   My father was a farmer in the east. Also farmed in western Canada.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

I wrote only a small child, but parents wrote at least once a month to relatives and friends.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Married to Francis William Whitten at Buttenau, North Dakota on Nov. 14, 1898.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

In our letters to friends we expressed the love and beauty of the new country, but no one needed recommending many were coming on their own.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

Came with parents, but my sister Mrs. Frank Hall and family had settled at Archie before we came. My brother Alex Stewart homesteaded at Louburn, Sask., same time as my sister.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

We had many experiences in pioneer life, but none stood out more.

For a number of years we loaded our grain to Weyburn with a horse and wagon. It took days to travel one. The second day we stopped for our annual goods such as flour, sugar, coffee, and tea. The third day we returned home.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Not very much traveling. Once or twice I traveled to Moose Jaw by train from Weyburn to visit friends and family. Visited friends around home by horse and buggy.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   First car in our community in 1911

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   Our car was a Model T Ford bought in 1914

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   First trading was done at Haliburk, then later to Wayburn.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   We traded to Wayburn to trade which was 35 miles, after 1914 we traded in Coalgate, 15 miles away. Finally, Madison 4 miles from home.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   About 3 times a year

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   No one in my town went to town regularly, only when necessary.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   About 1915 we first began to shop through catalogue. The order was mostly clothing. Never very often. Eaton's Winnipeg man.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   1920 provided by the North West Telephone Company

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   We came with the idea of making our home here. Of which we did.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

None

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

Some moved and did not return.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

None

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

Friend had a car 1907

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name, (2) origin and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption, (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

(Temple school) (district) named after Henry Temple, one of the first settlers
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe.)

None

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?

(Indicate your preference, if any)

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

Children:
- Ellen Johnson (Witterton), born Dec 27, 1899
- Reginald Alexander Witterton, born March 5, 1903 (Dakota)
- Donald Ed Witterton, born June 19, 1903
- Francis Elizabeth M. Seed (Witterton), born July 24, 1907

Grandchildren:
- 7

Great Grandchildren:
- 10

What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Grandfather:
- Josh Witterton
- 44 years
- 44 points, 6½, 4½, 8½, 10½
- Deep Bore, Sask.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:

Mrs. Francis M. Seed
Boy 1095 Weyburn 18, 4 Ave.
Sask.
The soil was worked up with grain and milking flax.

The Indians called in on their way to the Black Hills, and my father cut his fruit grain back again in the spring on their way to Arrow Mountain. They were friendly if you treated them well. We raised much all our food as children to always be nice to the Indians. My father cut down their from the turtle mountains to build our home.
The soil was worked up with open and walking plow. The Indians called in on this way to the Black Hills, and my father cut his first grain back again in the spring on the prairie, and tried by kind this way to avoid mountains through the four prairies. They were friendly if you treated them well. We were told as children to always be nice to the Indians. If my father cut down thus from the turtle mountains to build our home.
